ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_0: seething in the belly like molten brass,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_1: It is like pitch. It will fume in the belly
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_2: Like dregs of oil, it will boil in their bellies
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_3: It will be like molted brass which will boil in the bellies
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_4: Like molten copper; it churns in their bellies.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_5: Like boiling oil, it will boil in the bellies,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_6: Like dregs of oil; it shall boil in (their) bellies,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_7: like molten copper, bubbling in the belly
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_8: Like molten brass, it seetheth in their bellies
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_9: like the dregs of oil, it shall boil in their bellies,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_10: Like the dregs of all! It shall seethe in the bellies:
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_11: Like molten copper it will boil in their bellies,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_12: Like molten brass; it will boil in their insides.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_13: Like boiling oil, it will boil in the bellies,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_14: Like molten copper boiling in the belly
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_15: Like molten lead; boiling inside the bellies.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_16: Like murky oil, it boils within bellies
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_17: [44:45] Like molten copper, that is to say, like the dregs of black oil (ka’l-muhli, is the second predicate) it will boil inside the bellies ([if] read taghlī, then it is a third predicate; [if] yaghlī, then it is a circumstantial qualifier referring to al-muhl, ‘molten copper’),
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_18: (Like molten brass) and it is also said: black like the dregs of oil, (it seetheth in their bellies) it boils in their bellies
